raw_text:
A year to remember for Irish
 
 There used to be one subliminal moment during a year in Irish rugby that stood out more than most.
 
 Well, at least there used to one. Now there is a handful to look back with a mixture of satisfaction, and sorrow. It has been quite a year for the Irish, and not just with Eddie O'Sullivan's Triple Crown winning international outfit either. Right down through the ranks Irish rugby is creating waves and upsetting the more established teams in the game. But most of the kudos will go to O'Sullivan and his merry band of warriors who not only collected their first Triple Crown for 29 years, but also finished their autumn campaign with a 100% record. For the second year in succession they also finished in the runners-up spot in the RBS Six Nations. But in the three games in November which included a victory over Tri-Nations champions and Grand Slam chasing South Africa, Ireland finsihed the year on a high. The 18-12 victory at Lansdowne Road was only their second victory over the Boks after the initial success back in 1965. That success was revenge for the consecutive defeats in Blomefontein and Cape Town in the summer. Those two reverses and the 35-17 flop against France, were the only dark patches in an otherwise excellent 12 months. But the big one, of course, was the 19-13 defeat of World Cup champions England on their precious Twickenham turf. The winning try was conceived in O'Sullivan's mind, perfectly executed by the team and finished immaculately by Girvan Dempsey. For me, the try of the Championship. O'Sullivan's career is now in vertical take-off mode. It is no wonder that Sir Clive Woodward has elevated the Galway-based coach to head the Lions Test side. Not only that, but a fair majority of the present Ireland side will be wearing red next June in New Zealand.
 
 There can be no doubt that Ireland's representation will be the biggest ever, albeit in a proposed 44-man squad. In Brian O'Driscoll and Paul O'Connell, Ireland have now the two front-runners for the captaincy. Gordon D'Arcy, whose career began as a teenager back in 1999, finally arrived when he was named the Six Nations Player of the Tournament. But it was not only the senior squad that brought kudos to Ireland, the youngsters strutted their stuff on the big stage as well. The under-21 squad confounded the doubters as they went all the way to the World Cup final in Scotland only to be beaten by a powerful All Black side in the decider. The young Irish boys had stated their intentions earlier in the season when they finished runners-up to England in the Six Nations under-21 tournament. On the provincial front, Leinster, for second year in succession, blew it when the Heineken Cup looked a good wager. While Ulster finished runners-up in their very tight group for the second season in succession, it was Munster again flying the flag for the Irish. Looking to reach their third final, they went down 37-32 to eventual winners Wasps in what many beileve was the most competitive and thunderous game ever witnessed at Lansdowne Road. How Wasps recovered from that energy-sapping duel, and then go onto to defeat Toulouse in the final was anybody's guess. Ulster, meanwhile, just lost out to adding the inaugural Celtic Cup in winning the Celtic League when they were pipped at the post by the Scarlets in the final game.
 
 Ulster, however, took time to start the new season under new coach Mark McCall. The once famous Ravenhill fortress was breached four times as Ulster only manged five wins from their first 12 outings in the Celtic League. Leinster are again looking the most potent outfit going into 2005, but whether they can take that final step under Declan Kidney is another thing. On the down side, Irish rugby was hit by a number of tragedies. Teenage star John McCall died while playing for the Ireland against New Zealand in the under-19 World Cup game in Durban. That happened only 10 days after he led Royal Armagh to their first Ulster Schools' Cup success since 1977. The death of former Ireland coach and Lions flanker Mike Doyle in a car crash in Northern Ireland shocked the rugby fraternity A larger than life character, Doyle had coached Ireland to the Triple Crown in 1985, the last time that goal had been achieved before this season. Ulster rugby also suffered the sudden deaths of well-known Londonderry YM player Jim Huey, Coleraine's Jonathan Hutchinson, and Belfast Harlequins lock Johnny Poole. They all passed away long before the full-time whistle.
llama3.2:1b: Ireland's 2004 rugby season was marked by both success and tragedy.
The senior team finished with a 100% record in November, including victories over South Africa and England, but fell short of winning the Triple Crown for the first time since 1965.
The under-21 squad won the World Cup final despite being beaten in the decider by New Zealand.
Leinster lost to Wasps in their Heineken Cup campaign while Ulster finished runners-up with a 37-32 loss to Wasps.
Injuries also affected Ireland, including the deaths of three players - John McCall, Mike Doyle, and Johnny Poole - who all passed away before the end of the season.
llama3.2:3b: Ireland has had a memorable year in rugby, winning their first Triple Crown in 29 years under Eddie O'Sullivan, finishing with a 100% record in the autumn campaign, and defeating World Cup champions England on Twickenham turf.
The team will have a large representation at the upcoming Lions tour, with many players set to wear red for the test side.
Several Ireland players have achieved notable successes, including Gordon D'Arcy being named Six Nations Player of the Tournament, while under-21 squad finished runners-up in the World Cup final.
Irish provincial teams also had successful seasons, with Leinster and Munster reaching finals, but Ulster struggled to find consistency.
The year was also marked by tragic deaths of several young rugby players, including John McCall, Mike Doyle, Jim Huey, Jonathan Hutchinson, and Johnny Poole.
gemma2:2b: Ireland had a remarkable year in rugby.
The national team achieved its first Triple Crown in 29 years, finished second in the RBS Six Nations, and secured victories against South Africa.
The Ireland side's performance was highlighted by wins over England and South Africa.
Eddie O'Sullivan led the team to great success.
A large portion of the Irish rugby team will be competing for the Lions Test squad and many young players made notable appearances in the 2004 season.
The under-21s reached the World Cup final, and several teams across the provinces had impressive results.
The year was also marked by tragedy with the deaths of a number of prominent figures in Irish rugby.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A year to remember for Irish rugby is 2004.
Ireland won the World Cup again in 2005.
Ulster won a big game against Ulster University, but not so good.
Irish teenagers did badly in the Celtic League.
John McCall died playing for Ireland in a World Cup match.
Mike Doyle died in a car accident.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Ireland's 2004 season was marked by one standout moment for its rugby team, which saw them secure a Triple Crown and finish in the runners-up spot in the RBS Six Nations despite facing challenges from stronger teams like South Africa and France.

This success included victories over World Cup champions England on Twickenham turf, winning 18-13 after O'Sullivan's try, and finishing off an otherwise stellar campaign with a win over Tri-Nations champions before their final game of the season.
The team also performed well in under-21 tournaments and international competitions, including reaching the World Cup final but losing to New Zealand.
However, Irish rugby faced losses due to tragic deaths such as McCall's passing away from injuries sustained while playing for the Ireland against New Zealand during an under-19 World Cup game.
qwen2.5:3b: A year to remember for Irish Rugby saw significant achievements, most notably Eddie O’Sullivan’s Ireland winning their first Triple Crown in 29 years and finishing the RBS Six Nations as runners-up.
Key highlights include victories over South Africa and England, with the latter’s try being considered one of the Championship's best.
The Irish rugby scene expanded beyond senior teams, with under-21s reaching the World Cup final and provincial sides performing well in competitions like the Heineken Cup and Celtic League.
However, the year also brought several tragedies, including the death of John McCall and Mike Doyle, highlighting challenges within Irish rugby.
opencoder:1.5b:
A year to remember for Irish rugby

There used to be one subliminal moment during a year in Irish rugby that stood out more than most.
Well, at least there used to one.
Now there is a handful to look back with a mixture of satisfaction, and sorrow.
It has been quite a year for the Irish, and not just with Eddie O'Sullivan's Triple Crown winning international outfit either.
Right down through the ranks Irish rugby is creating waves and upsetting the more established teams in the game.
But most of the kudos will go to O'Sullivan and his merry band of warriors who not only collected their first Triple Crown for 29 years, but also finished their autumn campaign with a 100% record.
For the second year in succession they also finished in the runners-up spot in the RBS Six Nations.
But in the three games in November which included a victory over Tri-Nations champions and Grand Slam chasing South Africa, Ireland finsihed the year on a high.
The 18-12 victory at Lansdowne Road was only their second victory over the Boks after the initial success back in 1965.
That success was revenge for the consecutive defeats in Blomefontein and Cape Town in the summer.
Those two reverses and the 35-17 flop against France, were the only dark patches in an otherwise excellent 12 months.
But the big one, of course, was the 19-13 defeat of World Cup champions England on their precious Twickenham turf.
The winning try was conceived in O'Sullivan's mind, perfectly executed by the team and finished immaculately by Girvan Dempsey.
For me, the try of the Championship.
O'Sullivan's career is now in vertical take-off mode.
It is no wonder that Sir Clive Woodward has elevated the Galway-based coach to head the Lions Test side.
Not only that, but a fair majority of the present Ireland side will be wearing red next June in New Zealand.
smollm:1.7b: The Irish rugby team has been a dominant force in international competition for decades, with a rich history of success on the field.
The country has won numerous World Cup titles, Six Nations Championships, and other regional competitions throughout its history.
However, it is not just their individual achievements that make them stand out, but also their collective spirit and camaraderie.
The Irish rugby team's greatest achievement was winning the 1965 Six Nations Championship, a feat that has never been matched since.
The team's dominance in this tournament earned them the nickname "The Irish" and cemented their reputation as one of the greatest teams in international rugby.
In addition to their success on the field, the Irish rugby team is also known for its strong sense of community and camaraderie.
The country has a long history of supporting its national rugby team, with fans often going to great lengths to support their favorite players and coaches.
This sense of loyalty and dedication has helped to create a loyal following that continues to grow and evolve to this day.
The Irish rugby team's success on the field is not just limited to international competition, but also extends to domestic competitions such as the Ulster Schools' Cup and the Londonderry YMCA Cup.
These tournaments have produced some of the country's most talented young players, who go on to compete at the highest level in international competition.
Despite their many achievements, the Irish rugby team has not been without its setbacks.
In recent years, the country has faced criticism for its handling of injuries and controversies surrounding its national team.
However, the Irish rugby team has always demonstrated a strong commitment to fair play and good sportsmanship, earning them the respect and admiration of fans around the world.
In conclusion, the Irish rugby team is one of the most successful and beloved teams in international rugby.

With a rich history of success on the field, a strong sense of community and camaraderie, and a commitment to fair play and good sportsmanship, the Irish rugby team continues to be an inspiration to fans around the world.
As they look to the future, it is clear that their legacy will continue to endure for generations to come.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: A 2005 Irish rugby year marked significant milestones with Eddie O'Sullivan's Triple Crown win as a key highlight.
His efforts led to a strong season with multiple top performances, including a thrilling try at Twickenham and eventual recognition for his future success.
The team, building momentum from previous wins and revivals, continued their dominance in the game.
Notable players included Gordon D'Arcy and Brian O'Driscoll, while younger stars like Paul O'Connell and Brian O'Driscoll excelled under new coach Mark McCall.
The year saw strong performance against competitors and draws of players from other clubs, though some tragic losses impacted the team's momentum.
tinyllama:1.1b: A year to remember for Irish rugby is characterized by the Triple Crown winning international team of Eddie O'Suillivan, who also clinched a spot in the World Cup squad and the second consecutive defeat over South Africa.

The season also witnesses the loss of three key players: former Ireland coach Mike Doyle, Royal Armagh star John McCall, and Coleraine's Jonathan Huynson, Colelaure's Johnny Poole, and Londonderry YM player Jim Huytchinson.

However, the under-21 squad finishes runner-up to England in the Six Nations under-21 tournament, while Ulster rugby also suffers several tragic deaths: John McCall, who led Royal Armagh to their first Ulster Schools' Cup success since 1977, passes away, and Mike Doyle, who coached Ireland to the Triple Crown in 1985, dies in a car crash.
These events bring Irish rugby closer to reaching its goal of winning the Triple Crown and the World Cup.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In a remarkable year for Irish rugby, it was evident that there were numerous turning points, both positive and negative, throughout the season.
This highlights the significance of the year in Irish rugby, with many players striving to make their mark on the international stage.

The success of the Irish rugby team in the face of adversity is a testament to the perseverance and hard work of the players, as well as to the strong support they receive from their families, friends, and fans.
phi:2.7b:
A summary of the text is:

The text describes a year in Irish rugby, which was marked by several achievements and successes, such as winning the Triple Crown, finishing second in the Six Nations, reaching the World Cup final, and winning the Celtic League.
The text also mentions some tragic events that affected the players and their fans, such as a death in a car crash, and four player deaths in a short period of time.
orca-mini:3b: A year to remember for Irish rugby, with the country's senior team and young players showcasing their talent and earning plaudits.
The season included a 100% record in the Six Nations, a victory over World Cup champions England, and a runner-up finish in the Heineken Cup.
Leinster, Ulster, and Munster all had successful seasons, with Ulster narrowly missing out on the Celtic League title and Leinster winning their first Celtic Cup.
However, the season ended tragically for Irish rugby, with John McCall's death following a car accident just 10 days after leading Royal Armagh to their schools' cup win.
The death of former Ireland coach Mike Doyle and other senior figures in the game also left a lasting impact on the sport.
hermes3:3b:
Irish rugby year summary:
- Triple Crown and 100% record in international outings
- Second place in RBS Six Nations 
- Victory over South Africa, England, and other established teams
- Top representation in upcoming Lions Test side
- Under-21 squad reached final of World Cup
- Leinster won second Heineken Cup; Munster reached third final
- Ulster runners-up for Celtic League and inaugural Celtic Cup
- Tragedies: Teenage star John McCall's death, former Ireland coach Mike Doyle's car crash, and Ulster rugby players' deaths.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Ireland had a memorable year in rugby with Eddie O'Sullivan's team winning their first Triple Crown in 29 years and finishing with a 100% record in the autumn internationals.
They finished runners-up in the RBS Six Nations and celebrated victory over South Africa, England, and France.
The senior squad boasted talented players such as Brian O'Driscoll and Paul O'Connell, while the under-21 team reached the World Cup final.
Leinster and Munster also had successful runs in the Heineken Cup and Ulster suffered multiple tragic losses.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Ireland had a remarkable year in rugby, with success at multiple levels.

Eddie O'Sullivan's national team won their first Triple Crown in 29 years, finished as RBS Six Nations runners-up for the second consecutive year, and ended their autumn campaign undefeated, including a historic victory over South Africa.
Their biggest triumph was a 19-13 win over World Cup champions England at Twickenham.
O'Sullivan's rising reputation earned him the role of head coach for the Lions Test side, with many Irish players expected to be selected.
Brian O'Driscoll and Paul O'Connell emerged as captaincy contenders, while Gordon D'Arcy was named Six Nations Player of the Tournament.
Ireland's under-21 team impressed by reaching the World Cup final and finishing second in the Six Nations.
At the provincial level, Munster had a strong Heineken Cup run but lost to eventual winners Wasps, while Ulster narrowly missed out on the Celtic League title.
Leinster showed promise but struggled to take the final step.
The year was also marked by tragedy, with the deaths of teenage star John McCall, former Ireland coach Mike Doyle, and several Ulster rugby figures.
These losses cast a shadow over an otherwise successful year for Irish rugby.
stablelm2:1.6b: Irish rugby had a memorable year with various victories and setbacks.
Eddie O'Sullivan's team won their first Triple Crown in years, finishing with an impressive 50% record during the autumn campaign.
The Irish upset more established teams, including England at Twickenham.
However, significant moments included losing to World Cup champions South Africa and England twice during November.
Despite this loss, they finished on a high by beating Tri-Nations champions South Africa in three games.
Sir Clive Woodward elevated O'Sullivan to head the Lions Test side and appointed several Irish players for the New Zealand team.
The under-22 squad also performed well, reaching the World Cup final in Scotland before being defeated by a strong All Blacks side.
Ulster finished runners-up in their group for both the Heineken Cup and the Celtic League, while Leinster emerged as the most potent outfit going into the new season under coach Joe Schmidt.
However, Irish rugby suffered multiple tragedies with the deaths of John McCall, Mike Doyle, Jim Huey, Jonathan Hutchinson, and Johnny Poole before the end of the year.
granite3.1-dense:2b: 2004 was a remarkable year for Irish rugby, marked by significant achievements across various levels.

Eddie O'Sullivan's team clinched their first Triple Crown in 29 years and finished the autumn campaign with a perfect 10-0 record, securing the runners-up spot in the RBS Six Nations for the second consecutive year.
Notable victories included a 18-12 win over South Africa, an 19-13 triumph over England at Twickenham, and a strong performance against France (35-17).
Ireland's representation in the upcoming test tour to New Zealand is expected to be the largest ever, with Brian O'Driscoll and Paul O'Connell as top contenders for captaincy.
The under-21 squad reached the World Cup final in Scotland but lost to All Blacks.
Young players like Gordon D'Arcy, who was named Player of the Tournament in the Six Nations, showcased their potential.
At the provincial level, Leinster maintained second place in the Heineken Cup, while Ulster finished runners-up for the second consecutive season in the tightly contested group.
Munster advanced to the final of the tournament and delivered a memorable performance against Wasps, considered one of the most exciting games ever seen at Lansdowne Road.
Ulster, under new coach Mark McCall, struggled early in the Celtic League, losing their Ravenhill fortress four times before improving.
Leinster remains the most promising team going into 2005 but faces uncertainty with Declan Kidney at the helm.
Tragically, Irish rugby was hit by multiple deaths.
John McCall, an under-19 World Cup participant, passed away after leading Royal Armagh to their first Ulster Schools' Cup victory since 1977.

Former Ireland coach and Lions flanker Mike Doyle died in a car accident in Northern Ireland, while Jim Huey, Jonathan Hutchinson, and Johnny Poole from Ulster rugby all died prematurely before their respective games.
